pullRequest.body:
This PR contains a proof of Noether normalization lemma:
Let `A` be a finitely generated algebra over a field `k`. Then there exists natural number $r$ and an injective homomorphism from `k[X_1, X_2, ..., X_r]` to `A` such that `A` is integral over `k[X_1, X_2, ..., X_r]`.

Co-authored-by: Riccardo Brasca <riccardo.brasca@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Wan Lin <3438488340@qq.com>
Co-authored-by: Xiaoyang Su <12210823@mail.sustech.edu.cn>

---

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

Sure
Thanks! A few small comments

LGTM, but since I am a coauthor someone else should merge it.

maintainer delegate
I will have a look at the main file later today, but this looks good, thanks!
Can you add a short description of the strategy of the proof in the docstring at the beginning? It doesn't seem to be the same as in the stack project.
Thanks! A few small comments

I think this is really good and almost ready. In my opinion there are still two things to be done:

* you write a rather detailed proof strategy, but the description is before each theorem. I think it would be better to have it at the beginning of the file, with references to the actual declaration proving what you claim, maybe in a section "# Strategy of the proof" (for example you can say something like so that `T` maps
  different monomials of `f` to mvpolynomials with different degrees of `X_0`, see `name_of_the_theorem`).
* we try to have descriptive names even for private lemmas. I know, this is annoying but it helps).

The best thing would be to try to extract some results, but I don't know if this is reasonable, they all seem very specific to this proof.

LGTM, but since I am a coauthor someone else should merge it.

```suggestion
    ‚àë j : Fin n, (((n + 1 : ‚Ñ§) * up f) ^ (n + 1 - j.succ) * ((v j.succ) - (w j.succ))) = 0 := by
```

I think using the `Finset.univ.sup` of the `degreeOf`s works, or you can use `totalDegree` as well.

```suggestion
/-Suppose $f$ is a nonzero polynomial of $n+1$ variables : $X_0,...,X_n$.
We construct a ring homomorphism $T$ which maps $X_i$ into $X_i + X_0^{r_i}$ when $i \neq 0$,
and maps $f$ into some monic polynomial (regarded as a polynomial of $X_0$).-/

```
This docstring isn't specific to `abbrev up`.
You should be able to use `T_left_inv` to prove this ... if you generalize `T1` and `T_inv` by replacing `X 0 ^ r f i` by arbitrary polynomials in `X 0`.

Have you looked into [Nat.ofDigits](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Nat/Digits.html#Nat.ofDigits)? [Nat.digits_ofDigits](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Nat/Digits.html#Nat.digits_ofDigits) should give the injectivity easily. There is [List.ofFn](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Batteries/Data/List/Basic.html#List.ofFn) to convert a Fin tuple to a list.

It's not clear to me what this lemma is doing ...

`(monomial v a).degreeOf i` is the same as `v i` by [MvPolynomial.degreeOf_monomial_eq](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/MvPolynomial/Degrees.html#MvPolynomial.degreeOf_monomial_eq). I think you should use the shorter spelling in the statement.

```suggestion
  obtain ‚ü®d, l, rfl‚ü© := List.exists_cons_of_length_eq_add_one len.symm
```
Writing `rfl` will does `rw [eq]` everywhere, that is what you want (you have to remove all the `eq` from the rest of the proof).

```suggestion
    simp only [Nat.add_mul_mod_self_left, mod_eq_of_lt (w2 d <| List.mem_cons_self d l),
```
The namespace`Nat` is already opened (similarly below). Also, you can finish the proof with something like
```lean
simpa [mod_eq_of_lt (w2 d <| List.mem_cons_self d l),
      mod_eq_of_lt (w1 D <| List.mem_cons_self D L)] using H
```

```suggestion
local notation3 "up" => 2 + f.totalDegree
```
It seems better to have it as a simple notation (so it is completely transparent to Lean). Note that you have to remove `f` from `up f` everywhere.

```suggestion
private lemma up_lt (hv : v ‚àà f.support) (i : Fin (n + 1)) : v i < up := by
  have := (monomial_le_degreeOf i hv).trans <| degreeOf_le_totalDegree f i
  omega
```
Tow comments:
* we usually write `(i : Fin (n + 1))` rather than `‚àÄ i` in the statement.
* I used dot notation to avoid `le_trans` and `omega` that is better than `linarith` for goals about integers.

```suggestion
  rw [List.mem_ofFn, Set.mem_range] at h
  obtain ‚ü®y, hy‚ü© := h
  exact hy ‚ñ∏ vlt y
```
`variable {f v} in` makes `f` and `v` implicit in the lemma, no need to declare them twice.

You can even do
```lean
private lemma r_ne (vlt : ‚àÄ i, v i < up) (wlt : ‚àÄ i, w i < up) (neq : v ‚â† w) :
    ‚àë x : Fin (n + 1), r x * v x ‚â† ‚àë x : Fin (n + 1), r x * w x := by
  intro h
  refine neq <| Finsupp.ext <| congrFun <| ofFn_inj.mp ?_
  apply list_eq_of_ofDigits_eq (Nat.lt_add_right f.totalDegree one_lt_two)
    (by simp) (lt vlt) (lt wlt)
  simpa only [ofDigits_eq_sum_mapIdx, mapIdx_eq_ofFn, get_ofFn, length_ofFn,
      Fin.coe_cast, mul_comm, sum_ofFn] using h
```

```suggestion
`up` is defined as `f.totalDegree`. Any big enough number would work. -/
```
It's `f.totalDegree + 2`, no?


```suggestion
/-- We construct an algebra map `T1 f c` which maps `X_i` into `X_i + c ‚Ä¢ X_0 ^ r_i` when `i ‚â† 0`
and `X_0` to `X_0`.-/
```
Here you say "It maps `f` into some monic polynomial (regarded as a polynomial of `X_0`).". Do you prove this later in some sense?
How does `T1 f c` depend on `f`?
Because `r` depends on `f`.

```suggestion
/-- Let `I` be an ideal containing `f`. `hom1` is a homomorphism from `k[X_0,...X_{n-1}]`
to `k[X_1,...X_n][X]/œÜ(T(I))`, where `œÜ` is the isomorphism from `k[X_0,...X_{n-1}]`
to `k[X_1,...X_n][X]`. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- `hom1 f I` is integral. -/
private lemma hom1_int (fne : f ‚â† 0) (fi : f ‚àà I): (hom1 f I).IsIntegral := by
```
As the lemma is private, the docstring will not show up in documentation. A comment `/- ... -/` would do.
Should this be called something like `ofDigits_inj`?
Why do you need all these `rfl`s? Are there missing lemmas?
Sorry, but I have no idea how to get rid of these `rfl`s. Could you please give me some help?
Let me have a look.
When the cache is available...

The lemma we are missing is
```lean
namespace Ideal

variable {R S F : Type*} [Semiring R] [Semiring S] [FunLike F R S] (f : F)

lemma map_coe [RingHomClass F R S] (I : Ideal R) : I.map (f : R ‚Üí+* S) = I.map f := rfl

end Ideal
```
(you can put it after [Ideal.comap_coe](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/Ideal/Maps.html#Ideal.comap_coe).)

Then
```lean
private noncomputable abbrev eqv1 :
    ((MvPolynomial (Fin n) k)[X] ‚ß∏ (I.map (T f)).map (finSuccEquiv k n)) ‚âÉ‚Çê[k]
    MvPolynomial (Fin (n + 1)) k ‚ß∏ I.map (T f) := quotientEquivAlg
  ((I.map (T f)).map (finSuccEquiv k n)) (I.map (T f)) (finSuccEquiv k n).symm (by
  set g := (finSuccEquiv k n)
  symm
  have : g.symm.toRingEquiv.toRingHom.comp g = RingHom.id _ :=
    g.toRingEquiv.symm_toRingHom_comp_toRingHom
  calc
    _ = map (g.symm.toAlgHom.toRingHom.comp g) (map (T f) I) := by simp only [‚Üê Ideal.map_map,
      AlgHom.toRingHom_eq_coe, Ideal.map_coe, AlgEquiv.toAlgHom_eq_coe, AlgHom.coe_ideal_map,
      AlgEquiv.toAlgHom_toRingHom]
    _ = map (RingHom.id _) (map (T f) I) := by congr
    _ = Ideal.map ((RingHom.id _).comp <| T f) I := by rw [‚Üê Ideal.map_map, Ideal.map_coe]
    _ = _ := by rw [id_comp, Ideal.map_coe])
```
works. I wonder if it is reasonable to avoid the `symm`, but maybe not.
Even better, tagging `Ideal.map_coe` with `simp` the long `simp only` can be just `by simp [‚Üê Ideal.map_map]`.

The idea is the following: we prefer to avoid using `rfl` in proofs because if someone in the future change the definition the proof would break. What we prefer is to prove a lemma that can be rewritten instead of `rfl`. The proof of this lemma is `rfl`. In this way, if someone change the definition they will have to fix the proof of the lemma, but al the other proofs will automatically be OK.

```suggestion
  ¬∑ refine ‚ü®0, le_rfl, Quotient.mk‚Çê k I, ?_‚ü©
```
I would assume `Nontrivial` is non necessary. Also does your proof work for arbitrary domains (for `k`)?
Also can you upgrade `IsIntegral` to `Finite` using `RingHom.IsIntegral.to_finite`?
I also thought the same, but the statement is false for the trivial ring (one can add `FaithFulSmul k R` though, and then it is true).
Yeah makes sense. But you need `FaithFulSmul k R` for domains anyways.

I think this proof does not work for arbitrary domains `k`. If `k` is not a field, the lemma `T_leadingcoeff` will not work. Or is there a substitute for `Polynomial.Monic.quotient_isIntegral` used in lemma `hom1_int`?
Ah sure. You probably can't prove the domain version directly and it follows from the field version by looking at fraction fields.

The domain version won't work with IsIntegral even with the FaithfulSMul assumption; if k = Int and R = k[X]/(2X), then there's no injection from k[x_1,...,x_s] into R unless s=0 by considering transcendence degree, but when s=0, R is not integral over k, only algebraic.
It's interesting to check whether the proof works with IsAlgebraic (with appropriate modifications) though.
In my opinion we can focus on such generalizations later on (unless of course it's very easy).

Please write the type of the equivalence here:

```suggestion
private noncomputable abbrev eqv2 : sorry :=
  quotientEquivAlg (R‚ÇÅ := k) (I.map (T f)) I (T f).symm (by
```

```suggestion
  the different monomials of `f` to polynomials with different degrees in `X_0`. See `Nat.ofDigits`.
```
The name `Nat.ofDigits` now changed, right?


```suggestion

```

```suggestion
Second we construct the following maps: Let `I` be an ideal containing `f`.
  `œÜ : k[X_0,...X_{n-1}] ‚âÉ k[X_1,...X_n][X]`
  `hom1 : k[X_0,...X_{n-1}] ‚Üí k[X_1,...X_n][X]/œÜ(T(I))`
  `eqv1 : k[X_1,...X_n][X]/œÜ(T(I)) ‚âÉ k[X_0,...,X_n]/T(I)`
  `eqv2 : k[X_0,...,X_n]/T(I) ‚âÉ k[X_0,...,X_n]/I`
  `hom2 : k[X_0,...X_(n-1)] ‚Üí k[X_0,...X_n]/I`
`hom1` is integral because `œÜ(T(I))` contains a monic polynomial.
`hom2` is integral because it's the composition of integral maps.
```
Also, can you use the actual Lean notation (instead of `‚âÉ` and such)?

```suggestion
Here we choose `r_i` to be `up ^ i` where `up` is big enough, so that `T` maps
```

Since this is already in mathlib.
Can you add references to the actual statements?

```suggestion
  to `k[X_0,...,X_(n-1)]/I`.The case `n=0` is trivial.
```

```suggestion
For `n+1`, if `I = 0` there is nothing to do. Otherwise, `hom2` induces a map `œÜ` by quotient kernel.
```

```suggestion
  rw [‚Üê natDegree_finSuccEquiv, monomial_eq, Finsupp.prod_pow v fun a ‚Ü¶ X a]
  simp only [Fin.prod_univ_succ, Fin.sum_univ_succ, _root_.map_mul, map_prod, map_pow,
    AlgEquiv.ofAlgHom_apply, MvPolynomial.aeval_C, MvPolynomial.aeval_X, if_pos, Fin.succ_ne_zero,
    ite_false, one_smul, map_add, finSuccEquiv_X_zero, finSuccEquiv_X_succ, algebraMap_eq]
  have h (i : Fin n) :
      (Polynomial.C (X (R := k) i) + Polynomial.X ^ r i.succ) ^ v i.succ ‚â† 0 :=
    pow_ne_zero (v i.succ) (leadingCoeff_ne_zero.mp <| by simp [add_comm, leadingCoeff_X_pow_add_C])
  rw [natDegree_mul (by simp [ha]) (mul_ne_zero (by simp) (Finset.prod_ne_zero_iff.mpr
    (fun i _ ‚Ü¶ h i))), natDegree_mul (by simp) (Finset.prod_ne_zero_iff.mpr (fun i _ ‚Ü¶ h i)),
    natDegree_prod _  _ (fun i _ ‚Ü¶ h i), natDegree_finSuccEquiv, degreeOf_C]
  simpa only [natDegree_pow, zero_add, natDegree_X, mul_one, Fin.val_zero, pow_zero, one_mul,
    add_right_inj] using Finset.sum_congr rfl (fun i _ ‚Ü¶ by
    rw [add_comm (Polynomial.C _), natDegree_X_pow_add_C, mul_comm])
```

```suggestion
private lemma degreeOf_t_neq_of_neq (hv : v ‚àà f.support) (hw : w ‚àà f.support) (neq : v ‚â† w) :
```

```suggestion
  exact lt_of_le_of_lt ((monomial_le_degreeOf i ‚Äπ_‚Ä∫).trans (degreeOf_le_totalDegree f i)) (by omega)
```

```suggestion
  rw [monomial_eq, Finsupp.prod_fintype]
  ¬∑ simp only [_root_.map_mul, map_prod, leadingCoeff_mul, leadingCoeff_prod]
    rw [AlgEquiv.ofAlgHom_apply, algHom_C, algebraMap_eq, finSuccEquiv_apply,
      eval‚ÇÇHom_C, coe_comp]
    simp only [AlgEquiv.ofAlgHom_apply, Function.comp_apply, leadingCoeff_C, map_pow,
      leadingCoeff_pow, algebraMap_eq]
    have : ‚àÄ j, ((finSuccEquiv k n) ((T1 f) 1 (X j))).leadingCoeff = 1 := by  rw [monomial_eq, Finsupp.prod_fintype _ _ <| fun i ‚Ü¶ pow_zero _, _root_.map_mul, map_prod,
    _root_.map_mul, _root_.map_prod, leadingCoeff_mul, leadingCoeff_prod, AlgEquiv.ofAlgHom_apply,
    algHom_C, algebraMap_eq, finSuccEquiv_apply, eval‚ÇÇHom_C, coe_comp]
  simp only [AlgEquiv.ofAlgHom_apply, Function.comp_apply, leadingCoeff_C, map_pow,
    leadingCoeff_pow, algebraMap_eq]
  have : ‚àÄ j, ((finSuccEquiv k n) ((T1 f) 1 (X j))).leadingCoeff = 1 := fun j ‚Ü¶ by
    by_cases h : j = 0
    ¬∑ simp [h, finSuccEquiv_apply]
    ¬∑ simp only [aeval_eq_bind‚ÇÅ, bind‚ÇÅ_X_right, if_neg h, one_smul, map_add, map_pow]
      obtain ‚ü®i, rfl‚ü© := Fin.exists_succ_eq.mpr h
      simp [finSuccEquiv_X_succ, finSuccEquiv_X_zero, add_comm]
  simp only [this, one_pow, Finset.prod_const_one, mul_one]
```

The statement of this lemma seems weird: you are literally saying that `(finSuccEquiv k n (T f f)).leadingCoeff` is a unit (that is, different from `0`), right? I think it would be better to state it this way.
Let me see how I can modify this statement.

```suggestion
  induction n with
  | zero =>
      refine ‚ü®0, le_rfl, Quotient.mk‚Çê k I, fun a b hab ‚Ü¶ ?_,
        isIntegral_of_surjective _ (Quotient.mk‚Çê_surjective k I)‚ü©
      rw [Quotient.mk‚Çê_eq_mk, Ideal.Quotient.eq] at hab
      by_contra neq
      have eq := eq_C_of_isEmpty (a - b)
      have ne : coeff 0 (a - b) ‚â† 0 := fun h ‚Ü¶ h ‚ñ∏ eq ‚ñ∏ sub_ne_zero_of_ne neq <| map_zero _
      obtain ‚ü®c, _, eqr‚ü© := isUnit_iff_exists.mp ne.isUnit
      have one : c ‚Ä¢ (a - b) = 1 := by
        rw [MvPolynomial.smul_eq_C_mul, eq, ‚Üê RingHom.map_mul, eqr, MvPolynomial.C_1]
      exact hi ((eq_top_iff_one I).mpr (one ‚ñ∏ I.smul_of_tower_mem c hab))
  | succ d hd =>
    by_cases eqi : I = 0
    ¬∑ have bij : Function.Bijective (Quotient.mk‚Çê k I) := by
        refine ‚ü®fun a b hab ‚Ü¶ ?_, Quotient.mk_surjective‚ü©
        rw [Quotient.mk‚Çê_eq_mk, Ideal.Quotient.eq, eqi, Submodule.zero_eq_bot, mem_bot] at hab
        rw [‚Üê add_zero b, ‚Üê hab, add_sub_cancel]
      exact ‚ü®d + 1, le_rfl, _, bij.1, isIntegral_of_surjective _ bij.2‚ü©
    ¬∑ obtain ‚ü®f, fi, fne‚ü© := Submodule.exists_mem_ne_zero_of_ne_bot eqi
      set œï := kerLiftAlg <| hom2 f I
      have := Quotient.nontrivial hi
      obtain ‚ü®s, _, g, injg, intg‚ü© := hd (ker <| hom2 f I) (ker_ne_top <| hom2 f I)
      have comp : (kerLiftAlg (hom2 f I)).comp (Quotient.mk‚Çê k <| ker <| hom2 f I) = (hom2 f I) :=
        AlgHom.ext fun a ‚Ü¶ by
          simp only [AlgHom.coe_comp, Quotient.mk‚Çê_eq_mk, Function.comp_apply, kerLiftAlg_mk]
      exact ‚ü®s, by linarith, œï.comp g, (œï.coe_comp  g) ‚ñ∏ (kerLiftAlg_injective _).comp injg,
        intg.trans _ _ <| (comp ‚ñ∏ hom2_isIntegral f I fne fi).tower_top _ _‚ü©
```
I've slightly golfed this proof. The fact that if `I = 0` then `Function.Bijective (Quotient.mk‚Çê k I)` is bijective can be extracted as a sublemma (probably it makes sense to use `Quotient.mk`).
Can you write the statement rather then a description of the proof? If you want to describe the proof no problem, but do it inside the proof itself.
Again please describe the actual statement.

It seems we are missing a lemma here
```lean
theorem Algebra.finiteType_iff_algebraMap : FiniteType k R ‚Üî (algebraMap k R).FiniteType := by
  refine ‚ü®fun h ‚Ü¶ ?_, fun h ‚Ü¶ ?_‚ü©
  ¬∑ dsimp [RingHom.FiniteType]
    convert h
    exact algebra_ext (algebraMap k R).toAlgebra _ (congrFun rfl)
  ¬∑ dsimp [RingHom.FiniteType] at h
    convert h
    exact algebra_ext _ (algebraMap k R).toAlgebra (congrFun rfl)
```
(no need to assume `k` a field. It should go very close to the definition of `Algebra.FiniteType`). Actually we can even add
```lean
example {R S : Type*} [CommRing R] [CommRing S] [i : Algebra R S] : (algebraMap R S).toAlgebra = i := by
  exact Algebra.algebra_ext (algebraMap R S).toAlgebra i (congrFun rfl)
```

Then the proof can simply be
```lean
theorem exists_finite_inj_algHom_of_fg : ‚àÉ s, ‚àÉ g : (MvPolynomial (Fin s) k) ‚Üí‚Çê[k] R,
    Function.Injective g ‚àß g.Finite := by
  obtain ‚ü®s, g, ‚ü®inj, int‚ü©‚ü© := exists_integral_inj_algHom_of_fg k R
  have h : algebraMap k R = g.toRingHom.comp (algebraMap k (MvPolynomial (Fin s) k)) := by
    algebraize [g.toRingHom]
    rw [IsScalarTower.algebraMap_eq k (MvPolynomial (Fin s) k), algebraMap_toAlgebra']
  exact ‚ü®s, g, inj, int.to_finite (h ‚ñ∏ Algebra.finiteType_iff_algebraMap.mp fin).of_comp_finiteType‚ü©
```

```suggestion
## Strategy of the proof
```

```suggestion
# Noether normalization lemma
```

```suggestion
Finally, we use induction to prove there is an injective map from `k[X_0,...,X_{r-1}]`
```
`T_degree_inj` has changed name. Please check all the references.

```suggestion
Secondly, we construct the following maps: let `I` be an ideal containing `f` and
```

```suggestion
First, we construct an algebra equivalence `T` from `k[X_0,...,X_n]` to itself such that
```

```suggestion
Composing `œÜ` and `g` we get the desired map since both `œÜ` and `g` are injective and integral.
```

```suggestion
-/
@[stacks 00OW]
theorem exists_integral_inj_algHom_of_fg : ‚àÉ s, ‚àÉ g : (MvPolynomial (Fin s) k) ‚Üí‚Çê[k] R,
```

```suggestion
  obtain ‚ü®y, rfl‚ü© := h
  exact vlt y
```

```suggestion
private lemma t1_comp_t1_neg (c : k) : (T1 f c).comp (T1 f (-c)) = AlgHom.id _ _ := by
```

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).

By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ü§ñ). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
Can you please fix the conflict? Thanks!
I will have a look at the main file later today, but this looks good, thanks!
Can you add a short description of the strategy of the proof in the docstring at the beginning? It doesn't seem to be the same as in the stack project.
Thanks! A few small comments

I think this is really good and almost ready. In my opinion there are still two things to be done:

* you write a rather detailed proof strategy, but the description is before each theorem. I think it would be better to have it at the beginning of the file, with references to the actual declaration proving what you claim, maybe in a section "# Strategy of the proof" (for example you can say something like so that `T` maps
  different monomials of `f` to mvpolynomials with different degrees of `X_0`, see `name_of_the_theorem`).
* we try to have descriptive names even for private lemmas. I know, this is annoying but it helps).

The best thing would be to try to extract some results, but I don't know if this is reasonable, they all seem very specific to this proof.

LGTM, but since I am a coauthor someone else should merge it.
